Tech News

House Votes to Restore Net Neutrality Rules

In April, the US House of Representatives passed a bill called Save the Internet Act, which would restore net neutrality protections that the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) repealed last year. Even if it goes for a vote in the Senate and passes, many expect President Trump to veto the law.

Mueller Report Sheds New Light on How the Russians Hacked the DNC and the Clinton Campaign

The Mueller report, even redacted, reveals information about how Russian operatives hacked the Democratic National Convention. According to TechCrunch, the Russian government sent dozens of targeted spearphishing emails to the work and personal accounts of Clinton Campaign employees and volunteers to break into the campaign’s computer systems.

Ajit Pai Proposes $20 Billion for “Up To” Gigabit-Speed Rural Broadband

FCC chair Ajit Pai has proposed that $20.4 billion be allocated to efforts to expand broadband internet access to up to four million homes and small businesses in rural areas. The fund would reportedly operate by distributing the money to internet service providers through a competitive bidding process.

Apple and Qualcomm Settle All Disputes Worldwide

In what appears to be an end to extensive (and expensive) litigation between two technology giants, Apple and Qualcomm have reportedly settled all of their legal disputes worldwide. According to the New York Times, for the past two years, the two companies have been in ongoing financial disputes on three continents over the sale of smartphones and how to handle profits and sales.

SEO News

Google Starts Rolling Out Better AMP URLs

In a much anticipated move, Google is changing the way its Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) display URLs. Rather than display an “http://google.com/amp” URL, as the search engine has done for AMP pages since their inception, it will now show the URL of the publisher of the page (the same behavior as regular website pages).

Google My Business Lets Users Create Custom Short URLs

Google is rolling out a change for users of Google My Business that will allow them to create custom short URLs for their listings. Once a user has set this up, they can direct visitors to their profile page using a URL like “g.page/[yourcustomname]”.

Social Media News

Twitter to Launch a “Hide Replies” Feature, Plus Other Changes to Its Reporting Process

As part of a host of new measures intended to counter abuse on its platform, Twitter announced that it is experimenting with a new “hide replies” feature that will allow users to have more control over the comments that appear along with their tweets. Rather than simply blocking, muting, or reporting the commenter, users can hide those replies, though others can still click through an additional menu to view the hidden content.

Researchers Unearth 74 Facebook Cybercrime Groups With 385,000 Members

A Cisco security group has conducted research revealing dozens of Facebook groups dedicated to facilitating illegal activity, and whose membership numbers are in the hundreds of thousands. Facebook’s abuse-reporting systems were only marginally effective in removing the groups, and once some are removed, others appear in their places.

Jack Dorsey Says It’s Time to Rethink the Fundamental Dynamics of Twitter

At a recent TED event, Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey fielded questions regarding the company’s failure to consistently ban hate groups and other harmful content. He suggested that moving forward, it may be best to de-emphasize the importance of followers and likes, and restructure the platform to cater more to users’ interests, regardless of who posts the relevant content.

Legal Industry News

End of an Era: Tom Bruce, Trailblazing Director of LII, to Retire After 27 Years

Tom Bruce, co-founder of the Legal Information Institute and a crusader for free and open access to law, has announced his retirement after nearly three decades. Bruce’s work, which included publishing Supreme Court opinions online 10 years before the Court had a website, has increased public access to law for hundreds of millions across the globe.

Lawyer Fingerprinting in This State Turns Up Over 2,200 Convictions Unknown to Bar

Under a new rule requiring California lawyers to be re-fingerprinted, the State Bar has so far obtained confirmation of more than 2,200 convictions that were previously unreported. The Bar instituted this rule as part of its efforts to comply with a law requiring it to receive notifications of attorney arrests and convictions.

Would Millennial Lawyers Trade Pay for Better Work-Life Balance? A Significant Percentage Say Yes

A new survey indicates that about one-quarter of millennial lawyers at big firms would accept less pay in exchange for things like greater schedule flexibility and more time off. Most also agreed that attaining a law firm partnership is less desirable than it was a generation ago.

Why Cybersecurity Matters: A Lawyer’s Toolkit

Law firms are becoming increasingly attractive targets for hackers due to the nature and volume of sensitive data they house, compared to their relative lack of consistent security controls. Firms stand to not only lose revenue and productivity following a hack, but can suffer harm to their reputations as well.
